questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with golden-brown ring over iris on examination. What next is done to diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin

 

This is the most relevant test for the suspected condition. Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that binds copper in the bloodstream. In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin levels are typically low. Testing serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic step for Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Iron Level: While important in diagnosing conditions related to iron metabolism such as hemochromatosis or iron-deficiency anemia, serum iron levels are not directly relevant for diagnosing Wilson's disease. Hemochromatosis can also lead to liver damage but doesn't cause Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin: This test is used to diagnose alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a genetic condition that can cause lung and liver disease. However, it is not related to the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings and would not be the appropriate next step in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alpha-Fetoprotein: This is a marker often used in the diagnosis of liver cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma. While liver dysfunction is a component of Wilson's disease, alpha-fetoprotein is not a diagnostic marker for Wilson's disease and would not be the best next step in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings, it is crucial to evaluate for Wilson's disease, a condition of abnormal copper metabolism. Serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic test in this situation. Understanding the appropriate diagnostic approach for specific clinical signs is essential in guiding effective and efficient patient care.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ptosis

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that affects the cranial muscles, including the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs).
  • Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints in MG.
  • Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in MG.
  • The cranial muscles are typically involved early in the course of MG.
  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized.
  • Patients who only experience weakness in the EOMs for 3 years are said to have ocular MG.

 

Tensilon test:

 

In Myasthenia, there is improvement of ptosis with IV inj. of Edrophonium (Tensilon).

 

 

Lagophthalmos and Exophthalmos are signs of Thyroid Eye Disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diplopia: Common in MG but less frequent than ptosis.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Inability to close the eyelids completely, typically associated with thyroid eye disease or facial nerve palsy, not common in MG.

 

Option C. Exophthalmos: Protrusion of the eyeball, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in Myasthenia Gravis, a neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

Given the description of "Bilateral right sided loss of vision," the most likely site of the lesion would be the  Left optic tract. This type of visual field loss is consistent with the right visual field information being interrupted after the optic chiasma, which would affect the right visual field in both eyes.The optic tracts carry visual information after it has crossed at the optic chiasma. A lesion in the left optic tract would lead to a loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia). This is because the left optic tract carries information from the right half of the visual field of each eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Optic Tract: Similarly, a lesion in the right optic tract would cause a loss of vision in the left visual field of both eyes. This is also homonymous hemianopia, but on the opposite side of the visual field loss compared to a left optic tract lesion.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma can cause various types of visual field defects. The most common is bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This typically occurs with pituitary tumors that compress the chiasma from below.

 

Option D. Optic Radiation: The optic radiation carries visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex. A lesion in the optic radiation can also lead to homonymous hemianopia. The specific location within the optic radiation (e.g., Meyer's loop) can lead to more specific deficits like a superior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

questions.text: What is the indication of this procedure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratoconus

 

The given image shows the placement of Intacs, which is done for keratoconus.

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea.
  • Pathognomonic features include central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea.
  • Defective vision, progressive myopia, and irregular astigmatism are common clinical features.
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present.
  • Clinical signs: 
    1. Scissor reflex (yawning reflex) on retinoscopy is the earliest sign.
    2. Oil droplet reflex is seen with distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
    3. Fleischer’s ring (Epithelial iron deposits) and Vogt lines (Oblique stromal striae) (Image given below) are seen on slit lamp examination.
      Note: Kayser –fleischer ring is due to deposition of the copper and is seen in Wilson disease and chalcosis.
    4. Rizzuti's sign, a bright reflection from the nasal area of the limbus when light is directed to the limbus temporal area.
    5. Munson’s sign (localized bulging of the lower lid on looking down) is positive in keratoconus. (Image given below)
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Vogt’s line:

 

Vogt’s triad

 

Occurs centrally in a patient with keratoconus

  • Vertical stromal/ Descemet’s membrane lines.
  • Stress lines due to stretching and thinning.
  • Disappear with globe pressure.

 

 

  • The earliest way to detect any curvature disease of the cornea including keratoconus is topography (mapping of the point-to-point thickness of the cornea).
  • The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry.
  • Treatment: Declining visual acuity may not be corrected by glasses due to irregular astigmatism.
    1. In early cases:
      • Contact lenses (rigid gas permeable)
      • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments (flatten the cornea)
    2. In later stages: Penetrating keratoplasty may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's limbal girdle: Vogt's limbal girdle is a benign, age-related condition characterized by white, chalky deposits at the limbus. It is not treated with Intacs.

 

Option C. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a condition characterized by a generalized thinning and globular protrusion of the entire cornea. It is not typically treated with Intacs.

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic, often progressive, eye disorders in which abnormal material accumulates in the cornea. Treatment varies and does not typically involve Intacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The placement of Intacs is an indicated treatment for keratoconus, a condition characterized by the thinning and protrusion of the cornea leading to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

 

  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale centers, named after Moritz Roth.
  • Roth spots are classically described in and are considered as pathognomonic of Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis with the yellowish-white centre consisting of a focus of embolic infection.
  • They are commonly seen in other conditions as well.
  • In leukaemia, the white center typically represents fibrin-platelet plugs.
  • Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uveal melanoma: A primary cancer of the eye involving the iris, ciliary body, or choroid, not typically associated with Roth spots.

 

Option C. Uveal lymphoma: A rare type of eye cancer affecting the uvea, not commonly associated with Roth spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth's spots may be seen in -

 

1. Leukemia

2. Diabetes

3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis

4. Hypertensive retinopathy

5. HIV retinopathy

6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

7. Anemia

8. Pre-eclampsia

9. Anoxi

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presented with the following symptoms. What is the ideal treatment for the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate surgery

 

The image shows a 2-month-old baby with leukocoria, which refers to a white reflection in the pupil. The differential diagnoses for a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria include congenital cataract and congenital glaucoma. In both cases, surgery is the definitive treatment.

 

Congenital cataract is more likely in this scenario as the whiteness is confined to the pupil, whereas congenital glaucoma typically causes the entire cornea to appear hazy.

 

 

 

In both the condition, Immediate surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications like stimulus deprivation amblyopia, which can lead to permanent vision impairment if treatment is delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First try medical management: Medical management is primarily used to manage congenital glaucoma temporarily until surgery can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, immediate surgery is necessary.

 

Option C. Surgery after 2 years: Delaying surgery to 2 years increases the risk of amblyopia, a condition where the brain starts ignoring signals from the affected eye, leading to vision loss.

 

Option D. Surgery after 6 months of age: Postponing surgery to 6 months also poses a high risk of developing amblyopia, as early surgical intervention is critical to ensure normal visual development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria, immediate surgery is the ideal treatment to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

questions.text: A patient had a cataract surgery 3 years back, now complains of decrease in vision and presented with the following slit lamp image. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior capsular opacification


Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is the most common complication occurring after cataract surgery. It is often referred to as an "after cataract" or "secondary cataract." PCO develops when lens epithelial cells remaining after surgery migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule, which eventually leads to clouding.

 

The clinical presentation typically involves gradual vision loss without pain, as seen in this case. The slit lamp image provided shows an intraocular lens in place with opacification of the posterior capsule, which confirms the diagnosis of PCO.

 

The standard treatment for PCO is Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy, a simple and effective procedure to restore vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy: This condition occurs due to endothelial cell loss following cataract surgery, leading to corneal decompensation and formation of painful bullae on the corneal surface. It presents with pain and redness in the eye, which is not observed in this patient.

 

 

Option C. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophy is a genetic disorder that usually presents bilaterally and is unrelated to cataract surgery. It does not cause symptoms similar to those seen in this case and would not present specifically in one eye following cataract surgery.

 

 

Option D. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: This type of cataract develops in the back of the lens before surgery and is not seen after cataract surgery. Once removed during cataract surgery, posterior subcapsular cataracts do not recur.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication after cataract surgery, presenting with gradual vision loss without pain. It is treated with ND laser capsulotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pterygium

 

The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium.

  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.
  • It is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure.
  • It is more common in people living in hot climates, and a response to prolonged effect of environmental factors such as exposure to sun (ultraviolet rays), dry heat, high wind and abundance of dust.

 

Clinical features:

  • It is more common in elderly males doing outdoor work.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It presents as a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching the cornea in the area of palpebral aperture, usually on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side.
  • Deposition of iron seen sometimes in corneal epithelium anterior to advancing head of pterygium is called stocker's line.
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying of tear film.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Visual disturbances occur when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced due to fibrosis in the regressive stage.
  • Diplopia may occur due to limitation of ocular movements.
  • PARTS OF A PTERYGIUM:

 

A fully developed pterygium consists of three parts

  1. Head (apical part present on the cornea),
  2. Neck (limbal part), and
  3. Body (scleral part) extending between limbus and the canthus.

 

Differences between pterygium and pseudopterygium

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: A yellowish, benign growth on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea.

 

Option B. Concretions: Small, yellowish-white deposits on the conjunctiva, often associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea, commonly seen in people exposed to prolonged environmental factors like UV rays and dust. The treatment includes surgical removal and techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Homonymous hemianopia

 

The image shows a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision on the right side of the visual field in both eyes, which is termed as homonymous hemianopia. The term "homonymous" indicates that the defect is on the same side of the visual field in both eyes, while "hemianopia" refers to the loss of half of the visual field.

 

This pattern is typically caused by a lesion in the left optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe, which affects the visual field on the opposite side (right side in this case). The defect is contralateral to the side of the lesion, meaning that a left-sided lesion will produce a right-sided visual field loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopia: This condition involves the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, usually due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as from a pituitary tumor. The image does not show this pattern, as only the right visual fields are affected, not the outer fields.

 

Option B. Binasal hemianopia: This defect involves the loss of vision in the nasal (inner) fields of both eyes, often resulting from bilateral optic nerve compression. The visual defect in the image does not match this pattern, as it shows only right-sided field loss.

 

Option C. Altitudinal defect: This type of defect affects the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes, commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy. The image does not depict an upper or lower field defect; rather, it shows a loss on the right side of both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dermoid

 

Ocular dermoids are choristomas, containing tissue not normally found in the area. They often appear as round, firm, and sometimes hair-bearing lesions on the surface of the eye or near the eyelids as given in the image. Dermoids can vary in size and may cause astigmatism if they press against the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: This is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends onto the cornea. It often presents as a wedge-shaped, fleshy growth and is usually found on the side closest to the nose. Pterygium is often associated with exposure to sunlight or wind, and its symptoms can include redness, irritation, or a feeling of something in the eye.

 

Option B. Pinguecula: Similar to a pterygium, a pinguecula is a benign, yellowish growth that occurs on the conjunctiva. It typically appears on the side of the eye nearest to the nose but does not grow onto the cornea. Pingueculae are also associated with long-term sun exposure and can cause irritation or dryness.

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: This is a type of choristoma, like dermoids, but it primarily consists of fatty tissue. Dermolipomas are usually located on the outer corner of the eye and appear as soft, yellowish masses. They are generally benign and asymptomatic, but their size and location can occasionally cause cosmetic or functional concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

Paralytic Squint:

  • Caused by paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to nerve damage or muscle pathology.
  • Secondary deviation (movement of the non-paralyzed eye when the paralyzed eye is fixating) is greater than primary deviation.
  • The forced duction test is negative, indicating no mechanical restriction.
  • Patients may experience diplopia and adopt a compensatory head posture to minimize double vision.
