Additional Information

 

The squint may be either concomitant or incomitant.

• Concomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.

• Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

 

 

FORCED DUCTION TEST:

 

  • Performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of extraocular muscle and that due to mechanical restriction of the ocular movements.
  • FDT is positive (resistance encountered during passive rotation) in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction.
  • FDT is negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

  • The angle of deviation is the same in all directions of gaze.
  • Commonly seen in childhood and associated with hereditary factors, uncorrected refractive errors, or perinatal injury.
  • Diplopia is typically absent because the brain suppresses the image from the deviating eye.

 

Option B.  Restrictive Squint:

  • Caused by mechanical restriction of the extraocular muscles due to conditions like thyroid eye disease, trauma, or fibrosis.
  • The forced duction test is positive, indicating resistance during passive eye movement due to mechanical restriction.
  • Diplopia is often present, and the degree of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze.

 

Option D.  Pseudosquint:

  • An apparent squint where there is no actual misalignment of the eyes.
  • Commonly due to facial anatomical features such as epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge.
  • No actual deviation is present, and there are no associated symptoms like diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralytic squint is characterized by secondary deviation greater than primary deviation and a negative forced duction test, indicating the absence of mechanical restriction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presented with the following finding. What’s your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbal dermoid


A limbal dermoid is a benign congenital lesion often present at birth. It typically appears at the limbus, the border area between the cornea and the sclera, and is composed of dense connective tissue that can sometimes contain hair follicles or even teeth remnants.

 

The image shows a mass at the limbus, which is characteristic of a limbal dermoid. These lesions are non-cancerous and can sometimes cause astigmatism or irritation depending on their size and location.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papilloma: This option is incorrect because papillomas are epithelial tumors that usually present as small, fleshy, or warty growths on the conjunctiva. They do not typically appear as large, dense masses at the limbus.

 

Option C. Pyogenic granuloma: This is incorrect as pyogenic granulomas are fast-growing lesions that are often red, vascular, and prone to bleeding. They result from an inflammatory response and are usually not located at the limbus.

 

Option D. Pinguecula: Pingueculae are yellowish, slightly raised lesions located on the conjunctiva, usually near the nasal or temporal side of the cornea. They are associated with elastotic degeneration and do not encroach on the limbus.

 

Educational Objective:


A limbal dermoid is a congenital, benign growth located at the limbus, often containing connective tissue, hair, or teeth remnants, distinguishing it from other ocular lesions.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

 

  • The patient most likely contracted syphilis through unprotected sexual intercourse and later developed neurosyphilis as a consequence (neurological and visual disturbances).
  • Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is a condition characterized by intact accommodation reflex, but absent light reflex in the affected eye. (ARP-PRA)
  • Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:
  1. Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP):  Pupillary constriction when looking at near objects.
  2. Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Neurosyphilis is a manifestation of syphilis infection that affects the central nervous system, which occurs due to the invasion of the central nervous system by T. pallidum and can occur in any stage of syphilis.
  • Clinical features of neurosyphilis include:
    • Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs.
    • Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense.
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs.
    • Paraesthesia’s.
    • Bladder disturbances.
    • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting (visceral crisis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pupils react but do not accommodate: This is not characteristic of any specific condition and does not describe Argyll Robertson pupil.

 

Option C. Pupils neither react nor accommodate: This indicates more widespread dysfunction of the pupillary muscles and is not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Pupils react and accommodate: This describes normal pupillary function, which would not be expected in the context of the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.
